# Types of circuits

:::::{.columns}

### Parallel

## Electrons go the opposite way? Confusing! 

![](Pictures/wire-conventional-current.png){fig-align="center" .r-stretch}

Benjamin Franklin didn't know what electrons were: he took a guess about which direction things were moving, and he happened to guess wrong!

## Electrons go the opposite way? Confusing! 

![](Pictures/wire-conventional-current.png){fig-align="center" .r-stretch}

By convention, we always pretend that a <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="28" height="28" fill="red" class="bi bi-plus-circle" viewBox="0 0 16 16">
  <path d="M8 15A7 7 0 1 1 8 1a7 7 0 0 1 0 14m0 1A8 8 0 1 0 8 0a8 8 0 0 0 0 16"/>
  <path d="M8 4a.5.5 0 0 1 .5.5v3h3a.5.5 0 0 1 0 1h-3v3a.5.5 0 0 1-1 0v-3h-3a.5.5 0 0 1 0-1h3v-3A.5.5 0 0 1 8 4"/>
</svg> charge is going around the circuit -- even though it's just imaginary, it doesn't change how the circuit works.

::::
:::::

:::{.notes}
"Dumb" devices:
  * LDR -- Nightlight
  * Hall effect magnet sensor -- Door security sensor
  * Thermistor & Motor -- Automatic fan 
  * LDRs, Motor, & Solar panel -- sun-tracking solar battery
* "Smart" Devices
  * Thermometer & Air quality sensor -- Weather station
  * Camera & AI vision -- Train camera
  * Moisture sensor & Servo -- Automatic plant watering irrigation
  * Clock and LEDs -- visual alarm clock (wake up more naturally)
  * LDRs & RGB LEDs -- baby book, mushroom lamps
:::
